author: Michael Muncaster
title: UKIP leadership hopeful Lisa Duffy defends her call for ban on Muslim veils in public places
text:
UKIP leadership hopeful Lisa Duffy defends her call for ban on Muslim veils in public places 21:38, 8 Aug 2016 Lisa Duffy outlined her policies for the UKIP party at her first hustings held at the Marriot Hotel in Gateshead on Monday Shares Get daily news by email Lisa Duffy, prospective UKIP leader, at the Marriott Metrocentre 
A UKIP leadership candidate has defended her calls to ban Muslims wearing veils in public buildings and on public transport. 
Lisa Duffy said the move would help create a “well-rounded community” with “one rule for all”. 
But she has come under fire from critics who claim she was “chasing the bigot vote” and likened her to Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump. 
Speaking ahead of her first hustings event at the Newcastle Gateshead Marriott Hotel at the MetroCentre , Ms Duffy said: “It is a positive vision. 
“In high security situations, in shopping centres or on the bus someone may have to take off their motorcycle helmet or their hoodie. 
“It does not say in the Quran that the veil has to be worn so there is no reason why they can’t take it off.” 
Ms Duffy has also called for Islamic faith schools to be shut down in a bid to tackle radicalisation and for a ban on sharia courts in the UK. 
She argues that her proposals are designed to encourage integration. 
Ms Duffy, a councillor in Cambridgeshire, said: “It is important we have equality, opportunity and fairness. 
“British Muslims have the same rights as anyone else and they should feel British. 
“I want to stop the distance created between different groups in the community. All people should be treated the same.” Lisa Duffy, prospective UKIP leader, at the Marriott Metrocentre 
Former UKIP director Ms Duffy said being tough on law and order and supporting the NHS are her top policy priorities. 
She added: “I really want to build on our manifesto. We have voted to leave the EU and now we need to make sure we get the best Brexit deal. 
“Nigel Farage did an amazing job but it can’t be one individual. We need a strong team now to lead the party forward. 
“I have a lot of affection for the North East - the people wear their hearts on their sleeves and are very honest. 
“It is important to make sure that the North East and the north of the country are not forgotten.” 
Ms Duffy is up against UKIP MEPs Jonathan Arnott, who represents the North East, Bill Etheridge and Diane James, as well as national executive committee member Liz Jones and former parliamentary candidate Phillip Broughton. 
The winning candidate will be announced at UKIP’s annual conference in Bournemouth on September 15.
